results.title: What makes the wind blow?
results.creator_credit: Warren Brown, Stanley Croner and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth science series”.
This film studies the causes of a typical onshore sea breeze and a violent wind storm. It shows laboratory experiments designed to discover the possible causes. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Warren Brown, Stanley Croner and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films

results.title: Family Court
results.creator_credit: Peter Campbell, Diane Sundin, Family Court of Australia and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 58 of Series “English at work”.
This video explains the role of the Family Court in divorce cases. It explains the grounds for applying for divorce, and the issues involved in a divorce in Australia. It also explains options offered by the Family Court after an application for divorce has been made: the structure of Information sessions, conciliation conferences, and court counsellors to help resolve differences in the main areas of dispute; children and property.

results.title: Selection of dimensions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Engineering Drawing”

Introduces the principles which govern the choice of dimensions. These principles are shown to be based on two factors: (1) the functional characteristics of the object, which includes consideration of the accuracy demanded and the relation of the portion to other elements of the unit or machine; and (2) the manufacturing methods used in making the object.

results.title: Simple developments
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Engineering Drawing”.
Animated drawings are used in explaining what simple developements are and how they are made. Shows step-by-step, the development of a hexangonal prism, truncated cylinder, right rectangular pyramid, oblique pyramid, right circular cone, and truncated right circular cone.

results.title: According to plan
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Engineering Drawing”.
The aim of this film is to help the beginning student to get started on the right track in their thinking about engineering drawing. It tackles this objective partly through an emotional appeal based on the combined stimulation of emotion, sight and sounds, and partly on the development of the simple theme “modern production requires that many people work together on a single project”. To do this they need a language, a means of communication, so that their work can be co-ordinated. This language is engineering drawing.

results.title: Why do we still have mountains
results.creator_credit: Warren Brown, Stanley Croner, American Geological Institute and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth science series”.
Explains how mountains are formed by deformation of the Earth’s crust, showing that uplifting movements are occurring at present, and new elevations replace those being eroded.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Warren Brown, Stanley Croner, American Geological Institute and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films

results.title: Oblique cone and transitional developments
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Engineering Drawing”.
Animated drawings are used to show the development of the more complicated shapes. Shows an oblique cone, a transition connecting a circular and a square opening, and one connecting two curved openings. Demonstrates the use of true length diagrams and triangulation.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Engineering Drawing”.
Animated drawings are used to show the development of the more complicated shapes. Shows an oblique cone, a transition connecting a circular and a square opening, and one connecting two curved openings. Demonstrates the use of true length diagrams and triangulation.

results.title: Rocks that form on the Earth's surface
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance, Stanley Croner and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth science series”.
Explains the formation of sandstone and shale as typical sedimentary rocks, the process of compaction and cementation and the formation of limestone and coal. Uses examples and demonstrations to enhance the explanations.
